;“全职儿童”或“付费儿童”的概念 – 参考近几个月来，针对没有全职工作并与父母住在一起的年轻人，这在中国引发了激烈的争论。

;

;他们提供家务等服务，以换取父母和父母的经济支持。在某些情况下，他们可能会继续学业或尝试找工作。

;

;关于这一现象的许多讨论和媒体报道都集中在这些年轻人面临的挣扎以及为什么他们做出如此非传统的选择

;

;一些全职子女表示，他们厌倦了大城市竞争激烈的工作环境、漫长的工作时间和高昂的生活成本。但对许多人来说，原因更为明显：即使想要工作也找不到工作，所以他们只能回家和父母住在一起。

;

;由于二三十岁的人大多是独生子女，他们父母常常很高兴与他们共度时光。有些家长还给他们生活费，有时每月达数千元。

;

;“前景黯淡”还是一年4万美元？中国毕业生的情况截然不同

;

;典型的一天包括做饭、为父母购物、身体不适时带他们去看医生以及计划周末旅行。

;

;虽然一些社交媒体帖子这些全职孩子描述了离开工作生活的仓鼠轮子的田园生活，许多人也谈到了他们的挣扎，例如他们的焦虑以及来自父母或亲戚的压力，要求找到一份合适的工作并结婚。;

;大多数年轻人和他们的父母都将这种安排视为工作间隙的临时解决方案，也是别无选择时的最后手段。

;

;例如，一位来自陕西的女士在网上写道去年年底，她在全日制儿童论坛上称，她7月份从澳大利亚一所大学毕业后一直找不到工作，最终只能为父母做饭，以换取每月3000元（420美元）的津贴。

;

;她剩下的时间都在看小说，但她仍然希望自己最终能找到一份工作。

;

;这些父母中的许多人似乎已经六七十岁了，身体健康，但有时年轻人不得不辞去工作，照顾生病的父母。

;

;“这三年，我要么带着爸爸，要么带着妈妈去看医生。我没有挣钱，全靠父母。吉林的一位网友在一月份在同一论坛上写道：“这很丢脸，所以我除了上网聊天之外没有任何社交生活。”

;

;这种社会现象凸显了中国面临的两大问题：年轻人失业和人口迅速老龄化。

;

;今年，中国约有1158万大学毕业生进入劳动力市场，而6月份16至24岁人群的失业率创历史新高，达到21.3

;

;虽然人们希望第二个数字可能开始下降，但上海财经大学校长刘元春警告说，青年失业已成为一个结构性问题，需要立即解决或解决。它可能会变成一个政治问题。

;

;中国能否通过征兵来解决青年失业问题？

;

;与此同时，中国社会正在迅速老龄化。到 2035 年，近三分之一的人口（即 4 亿人）将达到 60 岁或以上。

;

;许多达到退休年龄的人只有一个孩子，这意味着一对已婚夫妇将不得不赡养四位老人

;

;对于全日制孩子来说，这或许只是暂时的安排，但却为中国争取了时间。这种情况如果持续到10年后是不健康的，那时他们的父母很可能已经接近80岁，可能真的需要全职照顾。必须尽快找到适合年轻一代和老一代的解决方案。

;美国对中国技术限制的任何放松都将是一场“艰苦的战斗”，因为分析人士表示，尽管北京和华盛顿之间最近恢复了高层会谈，但由于顶级芯片公司敦促拜登政府不要增加进一步的限制，国家安全问题仍令人担忧。

;

;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯会见据美国国务院称，美国芯片公司英特尔、高通和英伟达的首席执行官周一将讨论供应链问题以及中国对用于制造芯片的锗和镓的出口限制。

;

;还有报道称，美国商务部长吉娜·雷蒙多、国家经济委员会主任莱尔·布雷纳德和国家安全委员会主任杰克·沙​​利文参加了会议。

;

;半导体行业协会，一家总部位于华盛顿的贸易协会和游说团体该组织周一还敦促拜登政府避免对中国施加进一步限制，并允许该行业继续进入全球最大的半导体商业市场。

;

;“拜登政府，以及特朗普政府经济学人智库全球贸易首席分析师尼克·马罗表示，美国芯片公司正面临着一场“艰苦的战斗”。

;< p>;“对于企业来说，这一理由总是很难反驳，尤其是现在，因为美国对贸易、技术和台湾的担忧日益成为中美关系下滑轨迹的特征。”

;

;世界上的两个国家最大的经济体最近重启了双边谈判，美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯、财政部长珍妮特·耶伦和气候变化特使约翰·克里访问了中国。

;

;北京也对雷蒙多的访问持开放态度，谁负责监督与中国相关的贸易问题，包括对中国技术的出口管制，这导致双边关系紧张。

;

;人工智能会成为中国超越美国并成为顶级经济体的王牌吗？

;< p>;在最新的双边会谈中，半导体公司的一个主要担忧是华盛顿将在多大程度上继续遏制中国获取先进技术，包括进一步实施出口管制，以限制向中国出售一些人工智能 (AI) 芯片。

;

;美国还在考虑限制对中国科技行业的投资，包括芯片、人工智能和量子计算。

;

;马罗表示，美国正在努力说服日本、荷兰和其他市场对中国实施类似的出口限制。中国反映了对现有措施不足以阻止获得某些类型先进芯片的担忧。

;

;“方向是进一步收紧，而不是减少，”Marro 补充道。

;

; 10月，美国总统乔·拜登发布了一套旨在冻结中国半导体行业的全面规则，而美国却向自己的行业注入了数十亿美元的补贴。

;

;半导体行业协会还呼吁两国政府缓和紧张局势并通过对话寻求解决方案，而不是进一步升级。

;

;“我们的行动经过精心设计，重点关注具有国家安全影响的技术，旨在确保美国及其盟国的技术不会被用来破坏据路透社报道，白宫国家安全委员会表示：“我们的国家安全”。

;

;中国商务部本月初宣布从 8 月初开始限制镓和锗，以维护“国家安全和利益” ”此举被视为对美国支持的对中国半导体行业制裁的报复。

;

;麦格理集团周五表示，即使中美之间解决双边关系中的结构性问题也将很困难。预计将有更多高层会谈。

;

;“未来，美国将继续去风险化，中国将坚持自力更生。麦格理集团表示，期待已久的限制美国对华科技投资以及人工智能芯片出口限制的行政命令可能会在今年晚些时候推出。

;

;“在对两个国家实施出口管制之后，外交部发言人毛宁周二表示，中方希望美方为中美经贸合作创造良好环境。 ”。

;

;宁还重申中方反对“美国将贸易和科技问题政治化、武器化”。

;一头罕见的索马里野驴在智利动物园诞生，这是第四个标本动物园老板说，这种极度濒危物种将在这个南美洲国家诞生。

;

;

;仅存不到 200 头在野外，圈养的数量也相似。根据国际自然保护联盟 (IUCN) 的数据，其中 7 只在南美洲，全部位于圣地亚哥的布因动物园。

;

;狩猎和与普通家养驴杂交已经减少了驴的数量。这种动物已经到了濒临灭绝的地步，这是灭绝前世界自然保护联盟登记册上的最后一个类别。

;一篇基于 100 多名现任和前任麦当劳英国员工指控的爆炸性 BBC 文章描绘了这家快餐巨头有毒的工作文化，其中包括骚扰、性侵犯、种族主义和恐同症。

;

;在许多情况下，经理应对这些事件负责，无论是现任还是前任。工作人员告诉广播公司。年仅 16 岁的工人表示，他们在工作中受到性骚扰。

;

;在 BBC 为期五个月的调查中，听说一名餐厅经理建议一名 16 岁男工人进行性行为作为交换对于电子烟，另一位经理试图迫使新来的 16 岁女员工发生性行为，威尔士一家餐厅的男性经理和工作人员开玩笑说，打赌他们中谁会第一个和新员工上床。< /p>;

;一名前员工告诉 BBC，一名高级餐厅经理在她 17 岁时掐住了她的脖子并抓住她的臀部，一名值班经理还单独向她发送了露骨的色情照片。

;

;英国商业游说团卷入强奸指控的公司承认雇用了“有毒”人员

;

;一名员工表示，在她 19 岁时，一名男同事扇了她的屁股，让她别无选择，只能辞职。挫伤。这一事件被摄像机拍了下来，她向经理报告了这一情况，但她仍然被迫与这位同事一起工作，她说。

;

;“如果你在麦当劳工作，你会受到骚扰，这是人们的预期。” ”，一位前工人告诉 BBC。

;

;一些年轻女工表示，她们觉得自己不断受到外貌的评判，经理要求她们穿的制服太紧。

;

;“麦当劳有句俗话，‘t*ts onills’——男孩在厨房，女孩在柜台，”一名员工告诉 BBC。 “这个想法是把有魅力的人放在前面。”

;

;BBC 报道称，它还听到了种族主义的指控，包括一家餐厅的工作人员假装模仿一名来自印度的工人，说“胡言乱语”，一名工人对一名 17 岁的员工进行种族歧视，并说他想和她生一个“黑白”婴儿。

;

;一些工人表示，当他们报告这些事件时，经理们只是转移到同一特许经营网络中的另一家餐厅。有些人说他们没有抱怨，因为他们担心轮班被削减。

;

;在与 Insider 分享的一份声明中，麦当劳英国和爱尔兰首席执行官阿利斯泰尔·麦克罗 (Alistair Macrow) 表示，公司的每位员工“都应该在一个合理的环境中工作”。安全、尊重和包容的工作场所。”他说，麦当劳“对任何形式的骚扰都采取零容忍的态度”。

;

;“在某些情况下，我们显然没有做到这一点，对此我们深表歉意，”他继续说道。

;

;Macrow 补充说，英国麦当劳将调查所有指控。他说：“所有已证实违反我们行为准则的行为都将受到我们可以合法实施的最严厉措施，最高可达解雇。”

;中国领导人习近平和罗德里戈·杜特尔特周一的意外会面是为了争取支持分析人士称，随着马尼拉向华盛顿靠拢，习近平在菲律宾寻求更加友好的对华政策。

;

;周一在北京会谈时，习近平敦促菲律宾前总统杜特尔特“在友好合作中发挥重要作用”习近平表示，以亲华政策闻名的杜特尔特在担任领导人期间做出了改善与北京关系的“战略选择”，这有助于使两国关系“走向正确方向”据国家通讯社新华社报道。

;

;“中方一贯重视中菲关系，愿与菲方共同努力，推动中菲关系行稳致远” ”，习近平说。

;

;近几个月来，由于中国船只侵入南海领土，菲律宾与中国的关系一直紧张。北京声称对南海几乎全部海域拥有主权。

;

;新加坡尤索夫伊萨东南亚研究所客座研究员马波表示，这次会议可以被视为北京“国家元首外交”的延伸，并指出杜特尔特“几乎单枪匹马地改变了”马尼拉的对华政策

;

;“与杜特尔特的接触表明中国 — — 特别是习主席 — — 致力于向那些为加强与中国的双边关系做出贡献的领导人表示敬意，”马云说。南京大学国际关系学院副教授。

;

;“中国显然希望杜特尔特倡导与中国友好关系，但他们也希望他和他的政治联盟批评美菲关系在南中国海以及可能在台湾海峡对中国进行“魅力攻势”。”

;

;在去年上任的小费迪南德·马科斯总统的领导下，这个东南亚国家寻求与美国建立更温暖的关系

;

;菲律宾二月份扩大了与美国的一项军事协议，允许美国军队进入另外四个基地，其中一个距离台湾不远。 4 月，两国举行了为期 18 天的联合军事演习，约有 17,000 名士兵参加。

;

;同月，菲律宾外交部长恩里克·马纳洛和时任代理国防部长小卡利托·加尔维斯在华盛顿会见了两国同行之后，美国“加倍”致力于使 1951 年签署的共同防御条约现代化，双方就南海联合巡逻计划达成一致。

;

;国际关系学教授雷纳托·克鲁兹·德卡斯特罗 (Renato Cruz De Castro)德拉萨尔大学的研究人员表示，中国对小马科斯让美国在菲律宾拥有更大战略足迹的举动感到震惊。

;

;“中国对他们认为的反华政策非常担忧， “ 他说。 “习近平正在向[杜特尔特]的追随者传递一个信息，即中国更倾向于旧政策。他希望回到菲律宾绥靖中国时的情况。”

;

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 22:50:02 +0800 Taiwanese tycoon Terry Gou’s Washington Post op-ed hints he hasn’t ruled out presidential run, analysts sayhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3228142/taiwanese-tycoon-terry-gous-washington-post-op-ed-hints-he-hasnt-ruled-out-presidential-run-analysts?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 22:00;
;;

;台湾亿万富翁郭台铭将一个中国框架吹捧为避免这种情况的最佳方案a potential cross-strait conflict, a move experts say shows he has not given up on running in the island's presidential election.

;

;The Foxconn founder had hoped to represent the island's main opposition party, the Kuomintang, in the January race but failed to win the nomination. The KMT picked New Taipei Mayor Hou Yu-ih as its candidate in May.

;

;Most opinion polls in Taiwan, however, have put Hou in last place, trailing not only vice-president William Lai Ching-te of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) but also former Taipei mayor Ko Wen-je of the Taiwan People's Party, raising hopes for Gou to run.

;

;In an opinion piece published by The Washington Post on Monday, Gou said the independence-leaning DPP's policy of abandoning the one-China framework has turned the island into one of the most dangerous flashpoints for war in the world.

;

;“The current DPP leadership has only made the situation more tense,” Gou said.

;

;'Just a start': Taiwan ex-leader Ma welcomes academic team from mainland China

;

;Since being elected leader in 2016, Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen has refused to accept Beijing's interpretation of the 1992 consensus and the one-China principle.

;

;In 1992, Beijing and Taipei – then led by the KMT – reached an understanding that if the two sides were to continue talks, they must recognise that there is only one China, though each side could have its own interpretation of what that means.

;

;Gou said by refusing the acknowledge the consensus, the DPP wished to “walk away” from an understanding that had facilitated millions of cross-strait visits, massive investments and two-way trade, economic growth, hundreds of weekly direct flights, eased tensions and generated a sense of optimism about a peaceful future on both sides.

;

;He referred to “a number of productive agreements” signed by Beijing and the KMT government of former Taiwanese president Ma Ying-jeou, who led the island from 2008 until 2016.

;

;Gou said that Tsai's refusal to accept Beijing's interpretation, which includes Taiwan as part of China, had led mainland authorities to suspend cross-strait talks and exchanges since 2016.

;

;In the opinion piece, Gou also criticised Lai over his calls for Taiwan to reduce “dependencies” on mainland China and increase partnerships with other global economies instead.

;

;Gou said it was also wishful thinking for Lai to call for dialogues with Beijing “without precondition” as Beijing was unlikely to accept that if Lai did not support the one-China framework.

;

;Lai was nominated by the DPP in April to run for president in January. Tsai is constitutionally required to step down after finishing her second four-year term.

;

;In an opinion piece published by the Wall Street Journal on July 4, American Independence Day, Lai said he had no plans to declare independence for Taiwan and would support the cross-strait status quo and not rule out the possibility of dialogue “without preconditions”.

;

;“By abandoning the one-China framework for talks, the current leaders in Taiwan and those in their party who would replace them have greatly aggravated the threat of war, isolated Taiwan internationally, damaged our economy, scared away investors and made Taiwan less secure,” Gou wrote.

;

;He mocked the DPP for what he described as an “unhealthy dependency” on the United States, which has offered “material and moral support” for Taiwan over the past seven decades.

;

;“Taiwan has to take control of its destiny, strengthen deterrence capability and, at the same time, deliver an approach to peace that benefits the region and the globe, but most of all itself,” Gou said.

;

;Beijing claims sovereignty over Taiwan and has vowed to bring the island under its control, by force if necessary. Like most countries, the United States – Taiwan's biggest informal ally – does not support Taiwan as an independent state but is opposed to any unilateral change of the cross-strait status quo by force.

;

;“I have long advocated the immediate resumption of direct cross-strait negotiations between Taiwan and China as the only way to truly ease tensions and to preserve Taiwan's democracy, freedom, and rule of law,” Gou said.

;

;Analysts said Gou's view – which reads like a presidential campaign statement – outlined the cross-strait policy the wealthy businessman could adopt to distinguish himself from Lai.

;

;“Apparently Gou has not given up running for president and uses this statement to show that he would be a better leader when it comes to managing cross-strait relations,” said Wang Kung-yi, head of the Taiwan International Strategic Study Society, a Taipei think tank.

;

;By saying he would use the one-China framework to broker peace for Taiwan, Gou tried to tell the outside world that Lai's plan to maintain the cross-strait status quo and resume dialogues with Beijing is not feasible, Wang said.

;

;Beijing has stressed it would only return to the negotiation table on the basis of the 1992 consensus and one-China principle.

;

;Taiwanese presidential hopeful William Lai stresses cross-strait status quo

;

;Fan Shih-ping, a professor of political science at National Taiwan Normal University in Taipei, said the opinion piece was one of Gou's tactics to test the waters for a presidential bid.

;

;“In the past two months, Gou has been extremely active in visiting various parts of Taiwan, attending campaign rallies of local politicians and making speeches on what he believes is good for Taiwan. This obviously is to test the reaction of the public and to see if they would support him to run for president,” he said.

;

;However, Tseng Ming-chung, the KMT caucus head at the island's legislature, said he had “great confidence” that Gou would keep his promise to support Hou.

;

;“Gou had vowed to stump for whichever candidate from the KMT if he failed to win the nomination. He is a man of his word, and I have great confidence that he would help Hou in the campaign,” Tseng said.

;

;So far Gou has yet to say if he would help Hou in his run, but local news media said Gou was expected to announce his presidential bid next month as an independent candidate.

;

;Meanwhile, Taiwanese Premier Chen Chien-jen said Gou's proposal to embrace the 1992 consensus and one-China principle to ease cross-strait tension was unacceptable to the Taiwanese people.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 22:20:03 +0800 Brazil to investigate claims of Chinese dumping in optical cable sectorhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/3228148/brazil-investigate-claims-chinese-dumping-optical-cable-sector?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 22:04;
;;

;The Brazilian government has launched two investigations to determine whether Chinese companies that manufacture optical cables have engaged in unfair trade practice in the South American nation.

;

;The Brazilian Foreign Trade Secretariat will look into accusations of dumping – the trade practice of exporting goods at prices lower than the market rate, potentially creating an uneven playing field for local suppliers.

;

;Brasilia's Trade Defence department is also keen to determine whether these practices have been facilitated by subsidies from the Chinese government. Such actions would contravene World Trade Organization rules.

;

;The reviews indicate that despite Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's efforts to bolster diplomatic relations with Beijing, apprehensions remain regarding the potential impact on its economy, concerns that the United States and the European Union have also expressed recently.

;

;Discussions about the investigations were initially tabled in 2022, during Jair Bolsonaro's term as president, but have only recently been given the green light.

;

;Three multinational corporations – Italy's Prysmian, Mexico's Cablena and Japan's Furukawa Electric Co – advocated for it, contending they have suffered substantial losses in the Brazilian market after Chinese competitors used price manipulation tactics.

;

;The Brazilian Foreign Trade Secretariat reported that it has uncovered “substantial evidence” of intervention by Beijing, including subsidies and incentives fostering the development of raw materials for firms exporting fibre optic cables.

;

;Brasilia's investigation contrasts with the Lula government's efforts to increase diplomatic engagement with China. In April, the Brazilian president travelled to Beijing for a state visit and left saying that bilateral relations would reach “a new level” under his administration.

;

;5 trade moves China has made in 2023 in the US' backyard of Latin America

;

;Yet trade discussions remain a point of contention. For several years, Brazilian businesses has voiced grievances about perceived unfair practices by Chinese companies.

;

;In 2016, the Brazilian National Confederation of Industry, a consortium of Brazil's largest private-sector representatives, opposed giving China the “market economy” status, a label granted when supply and demand direct the production of goods and services.

;

;The WTO rules make it more difficult for Brazil to impose tariffs and duties on products of Chinese origin if it received the label. The confederation argued, however, that Beijing was artificially maintaining low prices through interventions proscribed by the WTO.

;

;During the presidential campaign in October, Lula said he was “shocked” by Chinese involvement in Brazil's economy. It was necessary, he claimed, to shed the illusion that China was “only dominating Africa” and recognise that the same was happening in Latin America.

;

;Recently, Lula and Argentine President Alberto Fernandez tried to deter Uruguay from pursuing a free-trade agreement with China. Brazil and Argentina voiced concerns that unchecked imports of Chinese products might pose a threat to the regional economy.

;

;Officials in charge of the case claimed that the evidence presented by Prysmian, Cablena and Furukawa “points to state interference in the sector, so that the decisions of private companies do not seem to reflect market dynamics, but rather constant guidelines of the plans established by the [Chinese] government”.

;

;The Chinese embassy in Brasilia said that it was “following the investigation and holding talks with the Brazilian side on the issue”.

;

;Marcelo Andrade, Prysmian's vice-president for telecommunications in Latin America, said the decision to ask the Brazilian authorities for a formal investigation was encouraged by resolutions favourable to the sector in the EU in 2021 and 2022.

;

;In November 2021, the European Commission found that manufacturers of fibre optic cables “benefited from preferential loans from the China Development Bank Fund” and approved anti-dumping duties on imports of single-mode fibre optic cables from China, setting a range from 5.1 per cent to 10.3 per cent in January 2022.

;

;“Despite the exponential growth of the domestic market, we have been losing ground since 2017 as Chinese companies have gained a foothold in Brazil with absurd pricing policies. The positive signal in Europe was an additional incentive to initiate the formal request for investigations, as this is a time-consuming, complex and very costly process,” Andrade said.

;

;He also said that during the internal preliminary negotiations for the investigation request, his team found dumping practices at several Chinese companies including Jiangsu Zhongtian Technology Co, Yangtze Optical Fibre and Cable, FiberHome and Hengtong. None of those companies responded to requests for comment.

;

;Carlos Eduardo de Oliveira, chief commercial officer at Cablena, said the goal was not to prevent Chinese companies from operating in Brazil, but rather to curb unfair competition and create a fair playing field in the sector.

;

;China, Brazil to sign more than 20 deals during Lula's state visit this week

;

;Cablena had suffered a 60 per cent drop in sales in Brazil in the last six years, Oliveira said, and had to lay off almost half of the more than 150 employees who worked in its factory in São Paulo.

;

;“The unfair competition caused by these Chinese companies discourages investment and prevents the development of emerging talent and Brazilian know-how in the technology sector. Many sectors of the economy have already been damaged [by unfair Chinese practices] and others will be destroyed if Brazil does not address the problem,” Oliveira said.

;

;The three companies are also considering investigation requests to other Latin American markets where they operate.

;

;While the imposition of anti-dumping measures is relatively common in Brazil, investigations into Chinese subsidies are quite rare and often face political and diplomatic hurdles.

;

;In 2017, officials from the Foreign Trade Secretariat affirmed such practices in the hot-rolled steel sector, with at least four Chinese firms allegedly reaping the benefits. However, a Brazilian ministerial council chose not to impose countervailing duties, citing a “public interest” in maintaining lower prices.

;

;Just last year, the Bolsonaro administration identified unfair Chinese subsidies on aluminium laminates but deferred instituting countervailing duties.

;

;But Lula's council of ministers revisited that decision and imposed duties of nearly 15 per cent for five years.

;

;Beijing opposed the tariffs and threatened to curtail imports of certain Brazilian commodities, government sources said.

;

;Brazilian Foreign Trade Minister Tatiana Prazeres said she could not comment on issues involving other governments, but assured that the analysis of the optical cables case, on which the investigation was predicated, followed only technical standards.

;

;“We have no restriction on the application of a countervailing measure, either against China or against any other country, provided there is evidence to justify it,” she said.

;

;Rafaela Noman, director of the trade defence department and responsible for the investigations, also said the Brazilian government has no intention – so far – of taking the matter to the WTO appeal panels.

;

;She said that procedures of this kind were only used in very large cases. If dumping practices and the granting of subsidies by the Chinese government are proven, Brazil would probably solve the problem through countervailing measures levied when the imported products arrive on Brazilian territory.

;

;3 reasons why China and Brazil are looking to deepen trade ties

;

;Silvana Schumanski, a former visiting scholar at the WTO and now a professor at the Federal University of Pelotas, said the investigations into subsidies and dumping by Chinese companies in Brazil are an indication that Chinese trade policy, while claiming to defend multilateral trade rules, has benefited from irregular practices with significant consequences for industry in developing countries.

;

;Schumanski argued that the prevailing sentiment among industry analysts is concern that China has leveraged its economic prowess to exert pressure on less affluent countries without facing repercussions for unfair competition.

;

;“No one really wants to discuss this issue, but it is clear that the standards and rules that exist today are not sufficient to deal [with some Chinese practices]. The result is that without equal bargaining power between a stronger and a weaker country, there is room for the big players to take advantage,” Schumanski said.

;

;Xi tells Latin America-Caribbean that China will take ties to 'new era'

;

;She expected that the investigations would be closely monitored by neighbouring nations, noting that Beijing's subsidies posed a risk to Latin American countries of “perpetuating a postcolonial trade paradigm”, given the concentration of production chains in Asia, especially in China.

;

;“For decades, our industry has withstood aggressive competition from the United States. Should we now simply substitute the Americans for China? That would be decidedly detrimental for Latin American countries,” Schumanski said.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 22:20:03 +0800 What is making 2023 likely to be the hottest year recorded?https://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/3228149/what-making-2023-likely-be-hottest-year-recorded?utm_source=rss_feed

;Human-made climate change is supercharging natural weather phenomena which is driving the heatwaves that are roasting Asia, Europe and North America – and could make 2023 the hottest year since records began, scientists say.

;

;Here, experts explain how 2023 has got so hot, warning that these record temperatures will get worse even if humanity drastically cuts its planet-warming gas emissions.

;

;After a record hot summer in 2022, this year the Pacific warming phenomenon known as El Nino has returned, heating up the oceans.

;

;“This may have provided some additional warmth to the North Atlantic, though because the El Nino event is only just beginning, this is likely only a small portion of the effect,” Robert Rohde of US temperature monitoring group Berkeley Earth wrote in an analysis.

;

;The group calculated that there was an 81 per cent chance that 2023 would become the warmest year since thermometer records began in the mid-19th century.

;

;'Hot and dangerous weekend': global heatwaves scorch the US to Asia and Europe

;

;The warming of the Atlantic may also have been sharpened by a decrease of two substances that typically reflect sunlight away from the ocean: dust blowing off the Sahara desert and sulphur aerosols from shipping fuel.

;

;Rohde's analysis of temperatures in the North Atlantic region noted “exceptionally low levels of dust coming off the Sahara in recent months.”

;

;This was due to unusually weak Atlantic trade winds, said Karsten Haustein of Germany's federal Climate Service Centre.

;

;Meanwhile new shipping restrictions in 2020 slashed toxic sulphur emissions. “This would not explain all of the present North Atlantic spike, but may have added to its severity,” Rohde noted.

;

;Warming oceans affect land weather patterns, prompting heatwaves and droughts in some places and storms in others. The hotter atmosphere sucks up moisture and dumps it elsewhere, said Richard Allan, professor of climate science at the University of Reading.

;

;Scientists highlighted the length and intensity of the lingering anticyclone systems bringing the heatwaves.

;

;“Where stagnant high-pressure areas persist over continents, the air sinks and warms, melting away clouds, causing intense summer sunshine to parch the soils, heating the ground and air above,” with heatwaves “lodged in place” for weeks, Allan said.

;

;In Europe, “the hot air which pushed in from Africa is now staying put, with settled high pressure conditions meaning that heat in warm sea, land and air continues to build,” added Hannah Cloke, a climate scientist at the University of Reading.

;

;2,000 evacuated in La Palma wildfire in Spain's Canary Islands

;

;Scientists at the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) said in their global summary report this year that climate change had made deadly heatwaves “more frequent and more intense across most land regions since the 1950s”.

;

;This month's heatwaves are “not one single phenomenon but several acting at the same time,” said Robert Vautard, director of France's Pierre-Simon Laplace climate institute. “But they are all strengthened by one factor: climate change.”

;

;Higher global temperatures make heatwaves longer and more intense. Despite being the main driver, climate change is one variable that humans can influence by reducing emissions from fossil fuels.

;

;“We are moving out of the usual and well-known natural oscillations of the climate to unchartered and more extreme territory,” said Melissa Lazenby, senior lecturer in climate change at the University of Sussex.

;

;“However, we have the ability to reduce our human influence on the climate and weather and to not create more extreme and long-lasting heatwaves.”

;

;Berkeley Earth warned the current El Nino could make Earth even hotter in 2024.

;

;The IPCC has said heatwaves risk getting more frequent and intense, though governments can limit climate change by reducing countries' greenhouse gas emissions.

;

;“This is just the beginning”, said Simon Lewis, chair of global change science at University College London. “Deep, rapid and sustained cuts in carbon emissions to net zero can halt the warming, but humanity will have to adapt to even more severe heatwaves in the future”.
